history.content:
<md>CS 170: Pretty necessary courses for algorithms that pop up everywhere and also extremely helpful for SWE interviews

CS 188: Chill class (hard exams) that gives an overview of all of AI. You should take this course if you aren't familiar with ML and want a taste of all aspects of it. For example, if you haven't ever heard of reinforcement learning or bayes nets or neural networks, this is a good light introduction. Not a very high workload class, but fills up quick. Doesn't really have any overlap with CS16c or 16B, those two are super fundamental EECS/CS courses on other topics. Since you aren't fixated on ML/AI yet, just take this class to see if you like it. (Personally recommend Prof. Anca Dragan, she is amazing) If you don't enjoy this class, then maybe AI/ML isn't for you. 

CS 189: Fundamental class on Machine Learning. Would highly recommend and also most advanced courses in ML require this as a "hard" prerequisite. Researchers often want an A/A+ in this for research consideration. Fall semester (Sahai) tends to be focused on theoretical ML (think longs PSets) while Spring semester (non-Sahai) tends to be practical/ industry focused (lots of coding and Kaggle submissions).

CS 182: Fundamental course on Deep Learning/Neural Networks, which is probably the most likely thing that you will use in ML industry and Research. Not too difficult, not too easy as a class. 

CS 194-80: Full Stack Deep Learning. This is the first year that this class has been taught and it is based on a boot camp of the same name. Gives full overview of ML in industry from training, to deployment to monitoring, etc.

Graduate courses like: 288 (NLP), 285 (RL), 280 (CV), etc. are very good for getting to know the state of the art for various subfields of ML

Fundamental courses like: EECS 127, EECS 126, EE 120 are good for foundational mathematics for AI and ML.

For your last question, the real answer is in one of the lectures from 194-80 where they brought in people who got a PhD, people who didn't, and the professor to give their viewpoints on whether you need a PhD to do ML.
 
The lecture is here: 
<iframe width="525" height="295" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sTxL2lspnTU?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

TLDW: There is a shortage of trained ML practitioners, and if you do graduate from Berkeley with a solid ML foundation, you most likely will be able to land some kind of ML job if you have some prior experience/ training. (papers, projects, competition submissions, contributions). 

You can definitely get a very decent job in ML/AI with just an undergraduate degree, but you will be working on projects and datasets that are specific to a company or business. This can be more interesting and more "SWE" since you will just be expected to get the SOTA models and algorithms and try a bunch of them to solve a problem. You will also be under all of the same constraints of working in a SWE job in a company, for the most part, but you can watch the last couple of lectures of FSDL if you want an overview of research and industry. I also lump masters into here because not all masters programs are intended for academia. For example, the 5th year masters seems to have an industry component to it.

If you get a PhD, you will be working on a tool rather than using it. Industry is like using a hammer to build a house. Research is like designing and experimenting with the next generation of hammers or other tools (Analogy from Pieter Abbeel) If you want to be designing and developing tools or algorithms, you might like a research/ PhD route. If you want to build interesting models or apps or programs with ML, you might like Industry a bit more.

There is also a non-obvious divide between industry and research. Plenty of research gets input and data from Industry to develop and deploy faster and more accurate models. Lots of big ML companies have research divisions for inhouse development and publishing of models and algorithms. </md>

children.subject: You could hold back on 61C if you want provided ypure not planning on 16x level courses. EE 16B however is essential linear algebra foundation required for 127,189 and signal processing for 120. You might be able to do without it for the linalg portion if you did Math 54.

<md>If you are a CS major and declared and you are confident enough, you could take 188 170 and another tech if you want. I would recommend getting the 61abc and 16ab out of the way as fast as you can as they give most of the fundamentals for lots of courses and are required to graduate. 

If you are good a Linear Algebra and Math in general, EE16B could be held off if you absolutely needed to, but I would just recommend you take it. 188's workload and content is closer to a moderate breadth rather than a full on technical course.</md>

Hm. I'll be honest; I'm a little scared taking eecs16b with Sahai if I take it fall 21, or taking cs61c with Weaver (either fall21/sp22). I tend to take a bit of time with both psets and projects, and probably will fare much better with slightly less workload, if possible.

That's why I thought I might want to wait until ee16b (sp22, Ranade) and cs61c later when Garcia teaches the course again—and take something else this sem. 

But I guess if I want to not have trouble with course selection in the following semesters, I should just suck it up and take either 16b/cs61c next semester(?). Do you know if Sahai's 16b workload is worth the pain, or should I take Weaver's 61c since I don't really have a choice if I want to finish all the lower divs by the end of my sophomore year?

<md>I would think that ee16b's workload is pretty consistent, I don't know if it has as drastic a change as 189 for content. You could wait, but then I would recommend finding something to fill the void of that tech. 188's workload is closer to a breadth or a light tech than the other classes, so I think that 170 + 188 + tech + breadth is a pretty reasonable schedule. </md>
so just to check, you don't really recommend Weaver's 61c?
I was also thinking of Data 8, but I hear that's more like a breadth.

<md>The reason I would pick between weaver and garcia is just preference for the lecturer. I don't know if either is harder than the other. 188 + 170 + 61c is doable (I did this with 127 and a breadth, but would not recommend loading up like this for the faint of heart)</md>

I'd recommend doing EE16B and 61C as early as you can, just because they're foundational for a lot of other classes (though 61C isn't as useful if you're just going to be focusing on ML/AI). I'd personally recommend 188 + 61C + EE16B next semester, and then 170 + 189 next semester (or you can postpone 189 until you've taken 127 or 110, depending on your comfort with linear algebra).

Okay wow. Thank you for all the information!

You make a great point about trying out 188 to make sure I do like AI/ML. But if I do take 188 with 170 next sem, I probably won't have room for other CS courses, which in turn means I have to put off 61C and 16B. And that might also lead to a delay in taking other courses that I might also need(?) since they are prerequisites for virtually all other upperdiv classes I've seen—and I'm not sure if I want to take EE16B and CS61C simultaneously. (Or should I?)

Am I just fussing over the next semesters' schedules too much, or do you think I should still consider this point when choosing courses for Fall?

<md>I took it with all 3 of them when they all taught 189 Fall 2020. If you consider a scale between theoretical and applied, Sahai is the professor most on the theoretical side and I would consider every other professor's offering to be more applied. However, the semester I took it, Sahai basically took charge of the class, so I don't really know what will happen with just Listgarten and Malik. </md>
The class will remain pretty theoretical compared to Spring.

Nicholas mentioned that Sahai's version of 189 is more theoretical, while other versions of the class are a bit more applied. I don't believe Sahai is teaching the class next Fall (it's with Listgarten and Malik), do you think that this course will be more theoretical or applied?

You can definitely do 16B / 188 / 189 at the same time. It won't be easy, but it won't be too hard either. 188 and 189 are pretty orthogonal in terms of content, so it's not necessary to take one before the other. Also, in terms of 189 in spring vs. fall, I took 189 in the spring with Shewchuk, but in general, neither is better than the other. I actually think that learning the theory is way more useful, especially if you're planning on taking courses after 189 (like 285 or 288).

All the "industry" application is going to be is a Kaggle problem every HW that lets you apply what you've learned (SVM, regression, LDA/QDA, etc.) to a problem, but it actually is not that useful. Industry ML is nothing like the problems you're going to be doing in 189, since it's going to be production ML and not just doing some toy SVM example on Kaggle (lots of industry problems mainly consist of modifying state of the art, open-source models and building out the surrounding architecture). Learning the theory can be incredibly useful for industry because it will help you gain a deeper understanding of what you'll be doing and help you gain intuition and make abstract decisions. So I'd argue that the "industry" stuff you do in 189 in the Spring is less useful than learning the theory, even if you're planning on going to industry.

<md>TBH learning to finetune a model or compress it is more relevant to industry than SVMs or whatever. If you are inclined towards industry, either versions of 189 can work. Then take 182 and 194-80 for more industry related experience. (194-80 will require at least an A-/A in 189 and 182, this is a strict requirement) The most relevant grad course for industry is 288 since it gives you experience with lots of NLP preprocessing and models. (For reference, the 182 homeworks for NLP were pretty much trivial if you copy and paste the hyperparameters from 288 projects)</md>

<md>Thank you for this detailed information! Not OP, but I'm also interested in ML. I have had *some* exposure to it through completing some courses in Coursera's deep learning specialization - I know that isn't anywhere near Berkeley's rigor, but I feel that I've learned enough to know that ML is something I'd like to pursue. 

I'm a freshman now, and I've taken CS 61A/61B, and Stat 140. This Fall, I'm taking EECS 16A and CS 70 - I was thinking of doing CS 188 but don't want to detract from focusing on CS 70 for declaration purposes. Is it a good idea to take EECS 16B + CS 188 + 189 next Spring (assuming I can get in - which might not happen if my declaration isn't processed soon enough)? I'd prefer to do something like CS 189 in Sp22 + CS 182 in Fa22, instead of delaying CS 189 to Sp23 (I'm trying to avoid Sahai's iteration as I'm inclined towards industry). 

Or would it be more doable (in terms of courseload and enrollment) to take CS 188 or 189 in Sp22, and take the other one in the summer? 
</md>

history.content:
Just a few questions about ML and related courses I should take.

I've taken CS61A/B, EECS16A, and will be taking CS 70 over the summer. I'll be a sophomore next semester.

I was thinking of taking CS 170 and CS 188 Fall 21, but I've been hearing mixed reviews on 188 and it seems like some people don't think 188 too necessary. Also, I'm not too fixated on ML, and probably should explore different topics a bit more—in that sense, would 188 be too narrowly focused on AI/ML? Should I switch 188 with CS61C or 16B instead? (if so, which one might be more manageable in terms of workload? I'm thinking of taking 170 + either one of 61c or 16b with Data 8 and an econ class.)

If I want to do ML, is just an undergraduate degree enough, or do I actually have to get a master's or a PhD to land some decent jobs?
history.subject: interested in ML...
